An enzyme that catalyzes hydrolysis of SM with optimal alkaline pH was first identified in the intestinal content of human and intestinal mucosa of rat and pig by Nilsson (10Nilsson Å. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1969; 176: 339-347Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar) and was named alkaline SMase (alk-SMase) thereafter (11Duan R.-D. Nyberg L. Nilsson Å. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1995; 1259: 49-55Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). Previous studies indicated that alk-SMase may be responsible for digestion of dietary SM and for hydrolysis of endogenous SM derived from bile and from the brush borders of sloughed mucosal cells. SM metabolism in the intestine may have implications in colon cancer development. Dietary supplement with SM and ceramide analogues was found to inhibit development of chemically induced colon cancer in animal studies (12Dillehay D.L. Webb S.K. Schmelz E.-M. Merrill A.H. J. Nutr. 1994; 124: 615-620Crossref PubMed Scopus (242) Google Scholar, 13Schmelz E.M. Bushnev A.S. Dillehay D.L. Liotta D.C. Merrill Jr., A.H. Nutr. Cancer. 1997; 28: 81-85Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar, 14Schmelz E. Bushnev A. Dillehan D.L. Sullards M. Liotta D. Merrill A.H. Cancer Res. 1999; 59: 5768-5772PubMed Google Scholar). We previously found that alk-SMase activity was significantly reduced in the tissues of human colon adenomas and carcinomas (15Hertervig E. Nilsson Å. Nyberg L. Duan R.-D. Cancer (Phila.). 1996; 79: 448-453Crossref Scopus (124) Google Scholar, 16Hertervig E. Nilsson Å. Björk J. Hultkrantz R. Duan R.-D. Br. J. Cancer. 1999; 81: 232-236Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar) and in the mucosa of longstanding ulcerative colitis (17Sjöqvist U. Hertervig E. Nilsson A. Duan R.D. Ost A. Tribukait B. Lofberg R. Inflamm. Bowel Dis. 2002; 8: 258-263Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar), indicating that the reduced SM hydrolysis in the gut may increase the susceptibility of the colonic mucosa to carcinogenic factors. SM metabolism in the gut may also affect cholesterol absorption, because both dietary SM in the gut (18Nyberg L. Duan R.-D. Nilsson Å. J. Nutr. Biochem. 2000; 11: 244-249Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 19Eckhardt E.R. Wang D.Q. Donovan J.M. Carey M.C. Gastroenterology. 2002; 122: 948-956Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar) and hydrolysis of SM in the membrane of enterocytes by SMase (20Chen H. Born E. Mathur S.N. Johlin Jr., F.C. Field F.J. Biochem. J. 1992; 286: 771-777Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar) were found to inhibit cholesterol absorption. We recently purified and characterized alk-SMase from rat small intestine (21Cheng Y. Nilsson Å. Tömquist E. Duan R.D. J. Lipid Res. 2002; 43: 316-324Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and human ileostomy content (22Duan R.D. Cheng Y. Hansen G. Hertervig E. Liu J.J. Syk I. Sjostrom H. Nilsson A. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 1241-1250Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). The enzyme has several properties that distinguish it from acid and neutral SMases. Its activity was not dependent on divalent ions such as Mg2+ and Ca2+, not inhibited by glutathione, and was resistant to trypsin digestion (11Duan R.-D. Nyberg L. Nilsson Å. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1995; 1259: 49-55Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar, 21Cheng Y. Nilsson Å. Tömquist E. Duan R.D. J. Lipid Res. 2002; 43: 316-324Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The enzyme activity was specifically dependent on taurocholate and taurochenodeoxycholate, two taurine-conjugated primary bile salts, and was inhibited by other common detergents such as Triton X-100 and CHAPS (21Cheng Y. Nilsson Å. Tömquist E. Duan R.D. J. Lipid Res. 2002; 43: 316-324Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). By using the immunogold technique, the enzyme was demonstrated on the surface of human intestinal brush borders, in endosome-like structures, and in Golgi complexes (22Duan R.D. Cheng Y. Hansen G. Hertervig E. Liu J.J. Syk I. Sjostrom H. Nilsson A. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 1241-1250Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Western blotting of rat tissues only found the enzyme protein in the intestine and not in other organs including brain, heart, lung, liver, kidney, spleen, and pancreas (21Cheng Y. Nilsson Å. Tömquist E. Duan R.D. J. Lipid Res. 2002; 43: 316-324Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Western blot also demonstrated that the enzyme protein was reduced in human colon cancer tissues compared with the surrounding normal tissues (22Duan R.D. Cheng Y. Hansen G. Hertervig E. Liu J.J. Syk I. Sjostrom H. Nilsson A. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 1241-1250Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). In this paper, from the purified enzyme we identified the full amino acid and cDNA sequences for the human intestinal alk-SMase. We found that the enzyme is a novel ecto-enzyme related to the nucleotide phosphodiesterase (NPP) family with specific features in terms of substrate specificity and metal ion dependence. Human small intestinal contents were collected from ileostomy stomas of six individuals as described (22Duan R.D. Cheng Y. Hansen G. Hertervig E. Liu J.J. Syk I. Sjostrom H. Nilsson A. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 1241-1250Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Bovine milk SM was provided by Dr. Lena Nyberg at Skåne Dairy Co. (Malmö, Sweden) and labeled with [14C-CH3]choline as described (23Stoffel W. Methods Enzymol. 1975; 36: 533-541Crossref Scopus (99) Google Scholar). DEAE-Sepharose, phenyl-Sepharose 6 FF, [32P]dCTP, [14C]palmitoyl lysophosphatidylcholine, [3H]choline chloride, and protein G-Sepharose were purchased from Amersham Biosciences. Uno Q anion exchange chromatography cartridge, pre-packed SE gel chromatography column, biologic HR protein purification system, and isoelectrofocusing instrument Rotofor were obtained from Bio-Rad. pCMV-Sport 6 with a cDNA insert (clone ID IMAGE 5186743) was purchased from ResGen (Huntsville, AL). pCDNA4/myc-His™B, anti-Myc antibody, and all primers used were purchased from Invitrogen. Anti-human alk-SMase antibody was developed in AgriSera AB (Vännäs, Sweden) using our purified human alk-SMase (22Duan R.D. Cheng Y. Hansen G. Hertervig E. Liu J.J. Syk I. Sjostrom H. Nilsson A. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 1241-1250Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Human digestive system Northern blot was purchased from Clontech (Palo Alto, CA). p-Nitrophenyl thymidine 5′-monophosphate (pNTMP), p-nitrophenyl phenylphosphate (pNPP), taurocholate (TC), ATP, ADP, AMP, neutral SMase from Bacillus cereus, and other chemicals used in characterization were purchased from Sigma. SMase Assay—Alk-SMase activity was determined by methods described previously (24Duan R.D. Nilsson Å. Methods Enzymol. 1999; 311: 276-286Crossref Scopus (58) Google Scholar). In the purification experiment, 5 μl of samples were mixed with 95 μlof50mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 9.0, containing 0.15 m NaCl, 2 mm EDTA, 10 mm TC (assay buffer), 0.1 mm SM, and 0.80 μm [14C]SM (∼8000 dpm) and incubated at 37 °C for 30 min. The reaction was terminated by adding 0.4 ml of chloroform/methanol (2:1) followed by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 10 s. An aliquot (100 μl) of the upper phase containing the cleaved phosphocholine was analyzed for radioactivity by liquid scintillation. For characterization studies, unless otherwise stated, the purified human intestinal alk-SMase sample was first diluted to 2.5 μg/ml. Five μl of the diluted sample was added in the assay buffer described above containing the reagents tested to a final volume of 80 μl. The reaction was started by adding 80 pmol of [14C-SM] (∼8000 dpm) in 20 μl of assay buffer. After 30 min of incubation, the reaction was terminated as above. The activity of neutral SMase was determined in a similar way with modifications of the buffer as described (21Cheng Y. Nilsson Å. Tömquist E. Duan R.D. J. Lipid Res. 2002; 43: 316-324Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Purification of Human Intestinal Alk-SMase—The purification of human intestinal alk-SMase has been described recently (22Duan R.D. Cheng Y. Hansen G. Hertervig E. Liu J.J. Syk I. Sjostrom H. Nilsson A. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 1241-1250Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Briefly the intestinal content collected was lyophilized and redissolved in ice-cold 0.15 m NaCl containing 1 mm benzamidine and 1 mm PMSF. The soluble proteins were precipitated by ammonium sulfate (55% saturation) at 4 °C. The precipitated proteins were dissolved in 20 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 8.2, containing 1 mm benzamidine and 1 mm PMSF and subjected stepwise to DEAE-Sepharose ion exchange chromatography, phenyl-Sepharose hydrophobic interaction chromatography, Uno Q high affinity ion exchange chromatography, native isoelectrofocusing, and SE gel chromatography. The purity of the enzyme was visualized by 10% SDS-PAGE, and the gel was stained by silver staining. Determination of Amino Acid Sequence and MALDI Mass Mapping of Fragments—The purified enzyme was subjected to 10% SDS-PAGE, and the enzyme was stained by Coomassie Blue. The stained protein band was cut from the gel and placed in an Eppendorf tube for in-gel digestion (25Oppermann M. Cols N. Nyman T. Helin J. Saarinen J. Byman I. Toran N. Alaiya A.A. Bergman T. Kalkkinen N. Gonzalez-Duarte R. Jornvall H. Eur. J. Biochem. 2000; 267: 4713-4719Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). Washing was carried out in 0.2 m ammonium bicarbonate containing 50% acetonitrile. The protein was reduced by dithiothreitol and alkylated by iodoacetamide, followed by in-gel digestion with 0.5 μg of trypsin (Promega, modified) in 0.2 m ammonium bicarbonate overnight at 37 °C. The tryptic peptides were extracted using acetonitrile in 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid, first at 60% and then at 40%. The peptide extracts were separated, and fragments were isolated on polyvinylidene difluoride membrane for sequence analysis using a Microblotter system (Applied Biosystems). Edman degradation of polyvinylidene difluoridebound peptides was carried out with a Procise cLC sequencer (Applied Biosystems) (26Bergman A.-C. Oppermann M. Oppermann U. Jörnvall H. Bergman T. Kamp R.M. Kyriakidis D. Choli-Papadopoulou T. Proteome and Protein Analysis. Springer-Verlag, Berlin2000: 81-87Crossref Google Scholar). MALDI mass spectrometry of tryptic fragments from in-gel digestion was carried out using Voyager DE Pro instrument (Applied Biosystems). Identification was based on comparison of theoretical mass values for tryptic fragments derived from the cDNA sequence and the masses detected in the in-gel digest (26Bergman A.-C. Oppermann M. Oppermann U. Jörnvall H. Bergman T. Kamp R.M. Kyriakidis D. Choli-Papadopoulou T. Proteome and Protein Analysis. Springer-Verlag, Berlin2000: 81-87Crossref Google Scholar). Transient Expression—Based on the information of amino acid sequence (415 amino acid residues) obtained from the purified enzyme, we found in the GenBank™ an incomplete cDNA segment (clone ID, IMAGE 5186743) which was derived from a pool of colon, kidney, and stomach and encodes our alk-SMase sequence. A plasmid containing the cDNA clone (pCMV-Sport 6) was then found commercially available and was purchased from ResGen. The cDNA insert of the pCMV-Sport 6 was amplified and sequenced. The translated amino acid sequence of the cDNA was compared with that obtained from purified human alk-SMase. To confirm that the cDNA does encode for human alk-SMase, COS-7 cells were incubated in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium with 10% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum and 2 mm glutamine. The cDNA insert in pCMV-Sport 6 was amplified by PCR using primers 5′-TCGGTACCGAAAGCATGAGAGGCCCGGCCGTACTC-3′ and 5′-TAGCGGCCGCCTGCGACCTCAGACAGAAGAAT-3′ and cloned into the mammalian expression vector pCDNA4/TO/myc-His B at KpnI and NotI sites. The COS-7 cells were transfected with the constructed plasmid in the presence of LipofectAMINE, followed by incubation of the cells for 48 h. Control cells were transfected with the mock plasmid in the same way as the transfected cells. At the end of incubation, the cell culture medium was collected, and the cells were lysed by a 50 mm Tris-HCl buffer containing 1 mm PMSF, 2 mm EDTA, 0.5 mm dithiothreitol, 10 μg/ml leupeptin, 10 μg/ml aprotinin, and 10 mm TC, followed by sonication for 10 s. After centrifugation at 12,000 relative centrifugal force for 10 min at 4 °C, the alk-SMase activity in the cell-free extract as well as in the cell culture medium of both transfected and control cells was determined. To confirm alkaline pH optimum, the SMase activities in the lysate of transfected cells were assayed in buffers with various pH values as described previously (21Cheng Y. Nilsson Å. Tömquist E. Duan R.D. J. Lipid Res. 2002; 43: 316-324Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Immunoprecipitation and Western Blot—The lysate of COS-7 cells (100 μl) after transfection was first pre-cleared with 20 μl of protein G-Sepharose at 4 °C for 1 h. After centrifugation, the supernatant was incubated with 1 μl of anti-Myc antibody for 1 h and then with 20 μl of protein G-Sepharose beads (50% suspension) for 2 h. The Sepharose beads were precipitated by centrifugation and washed 3 times with 1 ml of lysis buffer. The Sepharose beads were then resuspended in 10 μl of lysis buffer, and alk-SMase activity in 5 μl of the suspension was determined. Another aliquot of the Sepharose beads (10 μl) was boiled in electrophoresis sample buffer, subjected to 10% SDS-PAGE, and then transferred to nitrocellulose membrane by electrophoresis. The membranes were probed with either anti-Myc antibody (1:2000) according to the method of the manufacturer or with anti-human alk-SMase antibody (1:500) according to the procedures described previously (22Duan R.D. Cheng Y. Hansen G. Hertervig E. Liu J.J. Syk I. Sjostrom H. Nilsson A. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 1241-1250Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Second antibody conjugated with alkaline phosphatase was used, and color development was carried out by a kit from Bio-Rad. Determination of SM, Phosphatidylcholine (PC), and Lysophosphatidylcholine (Lyso-PC) in Cells—The determination of SM, PC, and lyso-PC in cells was performed as described previously (27Hedlund M. Svensson M. Nilsson A. Duan R.D. Svanborg C. J. Exp. Med. 1996; 183: 1037-1044Crossref PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar). In brief, COS-7 cells were labeled with [3H]choline chloride (0.5 μCi/ml) for 48 h and then transfected with the cDNA of alk-SMase or the vector alone as control. After 48 h of incubation, the total lipids in the cells were extracted and applied on a Silica Gel plate (60F, 0.25 mm) for thin layer chromatography. The plates were developed by chloroform, methanol, 25% ammonium hydroxide (65:25:4, v/v/v) and the SM, PC, and lyso-PC bands were visualized by iodine vapor. The bands were scraped according to the internal standard, and the radioactivities in the bands were determined by liquid scintillation. Northern Blotting Analyses—A 439-bp DNA fragment of pCMV-Sport 6 with the cDNA insert was amplified by PCR using primer (5′-GGCCCGAGACGGGGTGAAGGCACGCTACATGACCCCCGCC-3′) and (5′-TGGCCCGTGGAGTCCGGCTCCCC-3′). The DNA fragment and a control probe (glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase) were radiolabeled with [32P]dCTP by the random primer method to specific activities of 3–7 × 108 cpm/μg. Human digestive system Northern blot membrane was hybridized with the labeled probes at 50 °C. After washing, the membranes were exposed to x-ray film at –70 °C for 3 days. The membrane was then stripped with boiled water in the presence of 0.5% SDS for 10 min and rehybridized with the control probe. Phylogenetic Tree—The protein sequences of several members of ecto-NPP family including NPP1 human (P22413), NPP1 rat (NP_445987), NPP1 mouse (NP_067547), NPP2 rat (Q64610), NPP2 mouse (Q9R1E6), NPP2 human (Q13822), NPP3 human (O14638), NPP3 rat (P97675), NPP4 human (NP_055751), NPP5 human (NP_067547), the rat protein (XP_221184), and the mouse protein (XP_137914), which are similar to NPP5 human with unknown functions, were downloaded from the GenBank™ (28Benson D.A. Karsch-Mizrachi I. Lipman D.J. Ostell J. Rapp B.A. Wheeler D.L. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002; 30: 17-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (477) Google Scholar). To compare with human alk-SMase sequence, multiple sequence alignment was generated using Clustal W (29Thompson J.D. Higgins D.G. Gibson T.J. Nucleic Acids Res. 1994; 22: 4673-4680Crossref PubMed Scopus (55744) Google Scholar). The pairwise distances were calculated using the program PROTDIST, and the phylogenetic tree was created using the program NEIGHBOR from the PHYLIP program package. One hundred replicates of distance matrices were calculated for bootstrapping. Characterization of Purified Human Alk-SMase—The purified human alk-SMase was diluted to 2.5 μg/ml. Unless otherwise stated, 5 μl of the samples were used in the characterization studies. Effects of Mg2+, Ca2+, and Zn2+ were studied by determining the alk-SMase activities in the presence of various concentrations of the ions in 50 mm Tris buffer, pH 9.0, containing 0.15 m NaCl and 10 mm TC. The influences of ATP, ADP, and AMP were examined by preincubation of alk-SMase in the assay buffer containing one of the nucleoside phosphates for 15 min before addition of the substrate [14C-SM]. The effects of sodium orthovanadate and imidazole were studied by assaying the enzyme activity in the assay buffer with the presence of the substances. Whether alk-SMase has NPP activities was examined by using pNTMP and pNPP as substrates in four different buffers with various divalent ions as described below. First the NPP activity of alk-SMase was determined in the buffer optimal for its activity against SM. In a second experiment, the activity was assayed in 50 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 9.0, containing 0.15 m NaCl, 1 mm Ca2+, and 1 mm Mg2+ (30Clair T. Lee H.Y. Liotta L.A. Stracke M.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 996-1001Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar, 31Gijsbers R. Ceulemans H. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 1361-1368Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar). In a third experiment, activity was assayed in 50 mm Tris buffer, pH 8.0, containing 0.2 m KCl and 1 mm Ca2+ (32Moe Jr., O.A. Butler L.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 6941-6946Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Finally, the activities were assayed in 50 mm Tris buffer containing 0.15 m NaCl with different concentrations of Zn2+ ranging from 0.0125 to 2 mm. In all determinations described above, 1 mm pNTMP or pNPP was present as substrate, and the production of p-nitrophenyl was kinetically analyzed at 405 nm every 15 min up to 1 h on a microplate reader (Bio-Rad). Activity of Alk-SMase against Lyso-PC—To examine whether alk-SMase has activity against lyso-PC, purified alk-SMase (30 ng) was incubated with 25 nmol of [14C]palmitoyl-labeled lyso-PC in 50 mm Tris buffer, pH 7.5, containing 6 mm TC, 1 mm Mg2+, 1 mm Ca2+ to a final volume of 200 μl at 37 °C for 1 h. The reaction was terminated by adding 0.8 ml of chloroform/methanol (2:1). The upper phase was acidified by acetic acid to pH about 4 and discarded after stirring and centrifugation. The total lipids in the lower phase were dried under nitrogen, redissolved in chloroform/methanol (1:1), and applied on a Silica Gel plate (60F, 0.25 mm) for thin layer chromatography. The plates were developed with chloroform/methanol/acetic acid/H2O (50: 40:3:0.6) and stained with iodine vapor. The bands of lyso-PC and lyso-phosphatidic acid (lyso-PA) were scraped according to the positions of standard lyso-PC and lyso-PA. Under these conditions, the monoglyceride migrates with the solvent front and was also scraped. The radioactivity in each band was determined by liquid scintillation. Purification of Human Alk-SMase and Amino Acid Sequence—The procedure for alk-SMase purification followed the methods described recently, and the results obtained were similar (21Cheng Y. Nilsson Å. Tömquist E. Duan R.D. J. Lipid Res. 2002; 43: 316-324Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 22Duan R.D. Cheng Y. Hansen G. Hertervig E. Liu J.J. Syk I. Sjostrom H. Nilsson A. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 1241-1250Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). In brief, the enzyme was not retained in DEAESepharose column equilibrated with 20 mm Tris-HCl buffer containing 0.075 m NaCl. In phenyl-Sepharose hydrophobic interaction chromatography, the enzyme was retained on the column equilibrated with 20 mm Tris maleate buffer containing 1 m ammonium sulfate, pH 7.0, and eluted by ammonium sulfate at about 0.75 m. In Uno Q high affinity anion exchange chromatography using 20 mm Tris buffer, pH 8.2, the enzyme was retained on the matrix and eluted by the buffer with 0.05 m NaCl. In native electrofocusing, the enzyme was focused at pH 6.6. In final SE gel chromatography, the activity of the enzyme was identified in a single protein peak. The purity of the protein was shown in Fig. 1. One protein band with molecular mass of 60 kDa was demonstrated (lane C), which is slightly bigger than that of rat intestinal alk-SMase (lane D). The amino acid sequence of the purified enzyme was determined by MALDI mass mapping and Edman degradation. We amplified the cDNA insert, cloned it into an expression vector with a Myc tag, and transfected COS-7 cells. Both the cell number and cell protein concentration did not change significantly 48 h after transfection. However, as shown in the top panel of Fig. 3, the alk-SMase activity was markedly increased in the cDNA-transfected cells by about 689-fold. The activity was also increased by 27-fold in the culture medium of transfected cells (middle panel). We have purified wild type and exonuclease-deficient four-subunit DNA polymerase ϵ (Pol ϵ) complex from Saccharomyces cerevisiae and analyzed the fidelity of DNA synthesis by the two enzymes. Wild type Pol ϵ synthesizes DNA accurately, generating single-base substitutions and deletions at average error rates of ≤2 × 10-5 and ≤5 × 10-7, respectively. Pol ϵ lacking 3′ → 5′ exonuclease activity is less accurate to a degree suggesting that wild type Pol ϵ proofreads at least 92% of base substitution errors and at least 99% of frameshift errors made by the polymerase. Surprisingly the base substitution fidelity of exonuclease-deficient Pol ϵ is severalfold lower than that of proofreading-deficient forms of other replicative polymerases. Moreover the spectrum of errors shows a feature not seen with other A, B, C, or X family polymerases: a high proportion of transversions resulting from T·dTTP, T·dCTP, and C·dTTP mispairs. This unique error specificity and amino acid sequence alignments suggest that the structure of the polymerase active site of Pol ϵ differs from those of other B family members. We observed both similarities and differences between the spectrum of substitutions generated by proofreading-deficient Pol ϵ in vitro and substitutions occurring in vivo in a yeast strain defective in Pol ϵ proofreading and DNA mismatch repair. We discuss the implications of these findings for the role of Pol ϵ polymerase activity in DNA replication. We have purified wild type and exonuclease-deficient four-subunit DNA polymerase ϵ (Pol ϵ) complex from Saccharomyces cerevisiae and analyzed the fidelity of DNA synthesis by the two enzymes. Wild type Pol ϵ synthesizes DNA accurately, generating single-base substitutions and deletions at average error rates of ≤2 × 10-5 and ≤5 × 10-7, respectively. Pol ϵ lacking 3′ → 5′ exonuclease activity is less accurate to a degree suggesting that wild type Pol ϵ proofreads at least 92% of base substitution errors and at least 99% of frameshift errors made by the polymerase. Surprisingly the base substitution fidelity of exonuclease-deficient Pol ϵ is severalfold lower than that of proofreading-deficient forms of other replicative polymerases. Moreover the spectrum of errors shows a feature not seen with other A, B, C, or X family polymerases: a high proportion of transversions resulting from T·dTTP, T·dCTP, and C·dTTP mispairs. This unique error specificity and amino acid sequence alignments suggest that the structure of the polymerase active site of Pol ϵ differs from those of other B family members. We observed both similarities and differences between the spectrum of substitutions generated by proofreading-deficient Pol ϵ in vitro and substitutions occurring in vivo in a yeast strain defective in Pol ϵ proofreading and DNA mismatch repair. We discuss the implications of these findings for the role of Pol ϵ polymerase activity in DNA replication. Replication of chromosomes in eukaryotes is believed to require three DNA polymerases, Pol α, 1The abbreviations used are: Pol, DNA polymerase; Exo-, exonuclease-deficient; FOA, 5-fluoroorotic acid. Pol δ, and Pol ϵ (for reviews, see Refs. 1Burgers P.M. Chromosoma. 1998; 107: 218-227Crossref PubMed Scopus (163) Google Scholar, 2Shcherbakova P.V. Bebenek K. Kunkel T.A. Science's SAGE KE. 2003; (http://sageke.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/sageke;2003/8/re3)Google Scholar, 3Sugino A. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1995; 20: 319-323Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). Pol α has an associated DNA primase activity and synthesizes short RNA-DNA primers to initiate replication at origins and start Okazaki fragments on the lagging DNA strand. The roles of Pol δ and Pol ϵ in chromosomal replication are not clearly defined. Evidence for essential roles of Pol δ and Pol ϵ in replication comes from genetic studies in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Mutational inactivation of catalytic subunits and some of the additional subunits of both polymerases is lethal. Strains carrying temperature-sensitive mutations in POL3 gene (encoding the catalytic subunit of Pol δ), POL2, or DPB2 genes (encoding subunits of Pol ϵ) arrest in S phase of the cell cycle with a terminal morphology characteristic of a DNA replication defect upon shift to non-permissive temperature (4Araki H. Hamatake R.K. Johnston L.H. Sugino A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 4601-4605Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 5Araki H. Ropp P.A. Johnson A.L. Johnston L.H. Morrison A. Sugino A. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 733-740Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar, 6Hartwell L.H. J. Mol. Biol. 1976; 104: 803-817Crossref PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar). Incorporation of labeled precursors into DNA stops in these mutants at non-permissive temperature (4Araki H. Hamatake R.K. Johnston L.H. Sugino A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 4601-4605Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 5Araki H. Ropp P.A. Johnson A.L. Johnston L.H. Morrison A. Sugino A. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 733-740Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar, 7Budd M.E. Campbell J.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 496-505Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The POL3, POL2, and DPB2 genes, as well as the DPB3 gene encoding the third subunit of Pol ϵ, are expressed periodically in the cell cycle with a peak in G1 to S phase transition (4Araki H. Hamatake R.K. Johnston L.H. Sugino A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 4601-4605Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 5Araki H. Ropp P.A. Johnson A.L. Johnston L.H. Morrison A. Sugino A. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 733-740Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar, 8Araki H. Hamatake R.K. Morrison A. Johnson A.L. Johnston L.H. Sugino A. Nucleic Acids Res. 1991; 19: 4867-4872Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar), which is characteristic of genes encoding DNA replication proteins. Both Pol δ and Pol ϵ have intrinsic 3′ → 5′ exonuclease activities that correct polymerase errors during replication (9Morrison A. Johnson A.L. Johnston L.H. Sugino A. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 1467-1473Crossref PubMed Scopus (227) Google Scholar, 10Morrison A. Sugino A. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1994; 242: 289-296Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar). Mutations in POL3 or POL2 inactivating the exonucleases result in a mutator phenotype (11Morrison A. Bell J.B. Kunkel T.A. Sugino A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 9473-9477Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar, 12Simon M. Giot L. Faye G. EMBO J. 1991; 10: 2165-2170Crossref PubMed Scopus (183) Google Scholar). To accommodate roles for Pol δ and Pol ϵ at a replication fork, it was proposed that Pol ϵ elongates the leading DNA strand, while Pol δ elongates Okazaki fragments on the lagging DNA strand (13Morrison A. Araki H. Clark A.B. Hamatake R.K. Sugino A. Cell. 1990; 62: 1143-1151Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (277) Google Scholar). Other models for the roles of Pol δ and Pol ϵ in chromosomal replication have also been considered (14Linn S. Cell. 1991; 66: 185-187Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar, 15Burgers P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22698-22706Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). “One strand-one polymerase” models are consistent with the observation that both polymerases are monomers in solution (16Johansson E. Majka J. Burgers P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 43824-43828Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 17Chilkova O. Jonsson B.H. Johansson E. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 14082-14086Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar) and with our earlier genetic studies demonstrating that the 3′ → 5′ exonucleases of Pol δ and Pol ϵ correct replication errors on opposite DNA strands (18Shcherbakova P.V. Pavlov Y.I. Genetics. 1996; 142: 717-726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). However, it is not yet known whether Pol δ and Pol ϵ always correct their own errors in vivo, and genetic data on the roles of Pol δ and Pol ϵ exonucleases are not sufficient to conclude that the two polymerases perform synthesis on opposite DNA strands. Pol ϵ belongs to the B family of DNA polymerases that includes Pol α and Pol δ as well as DNA polymerases that replicate genomes of bacteriophages T4 and RB69. The B family also includes the eukaryotic DNA polymerase ζ, a translesion synthesis polymerase that is not essential for chromosomal DNA replication in yeast. A unique feature of Pol ϵ is that the catalytic subunit contains a large C-terminal domain that is not present in other B family DNA polymerases. This domain is needed for interaction of the catalytic subunit with the other subunits of the Pol ϵ holoenzyme and for the function of Pol ϵ in S phase checkpoint control (13Morrison A. Araki H. Clark A.B. Hamatake R.K. Sugino A. Cell. 1990; 62: 1143-1151Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (277) Google Scholar, 19Dua R. Levy D.L. Campbell J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30046-30055Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar, 20Dua R. Levy D.L. Campbell J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22283-22288Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar, 21Navas T.A. Zhou Z. Elledge S.J. Cell. 1995; 80: 29-39Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (370) Google Scholar). The essential role of Pol ϵ polymerase activity in replication was questioned by the observation that only the C-terminal domain of the catalytic subunit is required for cell viability, while mutants with a deletion of the N-terminal domain, which contains all the conserved DNA polymerase motifs, survive (22Kesti T. Flick K. Keranen S. Syvaoja J.E. Wittenberg C. Mol. Cell. 1999; 3: 679-685Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (225) Google Scholar). However, these mutants display severe growth and replication defects (23Ohya T. Kawasaki Y. Hiraga S. Kanbara S. Nakajo K. Nakashima N. Suzuki A. Sugino A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 28099-28108Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar). Moreover single amino acid substitutions in the polymerase active site of Pol ϵ are lethal (20Dua R. Levy D.L. Campbell J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22283-22288Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar, 24Pavlov Y.I. Shcherbakova P.V. Kunkel T.A. Genetics. 2001; 159: 47-64PubMed Google Scholar). One explanation for these observations is that Pol ϵ is normally a component of the replication machinery, but when absent, it can be partially substituted for by another DNA polymerase. It was also suggested that Pol ϵ participates in DNA replication during late but not early S phase in human cells (25Fuss J. Linn S. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 8658-8666Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). A property of replication that is critical for genome stability is the fidelity of DNA synthesis. An initial study conducted 12 years ago (26Thomas D.C. Roberts J.D. Sabatino R.D. Myers T.W. Tan C.K. Downey K.M. So A.G. Bambara R.A. Kunkel T.A. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 11751-11759Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar) demonstrated that the catalytic subunit of calf thymus Pol ϵ synthesized DNA with high fidelity. A more recent kinetic analysis of fidelity (27Shimizu K. Hashimoto K. Kirchner J.M. Nakai W. Nishikawa H. Resnick M.A. Sugino A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37422-37429Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar) demonstrated that yeast Pol ϵ efficiently prevents nucleotide misinsertion at one template position and that two of the three possible mismatches at that site can be excised by the 3′ → 5′ exonuclease of Pol ϵ, indicating that yeast Pol ϵ can conduct accurate DNA synthesis. Just how accurate yeast Pol ϵ is for all 12 mispairs in different sequence contexts and how efficiently it prevents and proofreads insertion and deletion errors are unknown. With this in mind and with the goal to eventually understand the role of yeast Pol ϵ in replicating one or both strands of the 12 million-nucleotide yeast genome and stably maintaining it in the face of DNA damage, here we characterize the fidelity of DNA synthesis by wild type and proofreading-deficient forms of yeast Pol ϵ holoenzyme. We provide a comprehensive description of error rates in many sequence contexts for all 12 single-base mismatches as well as for single-base additions and single-base and larger deletions. We confirm that Pol ϵ is highly accurate, describe the contribution of proofreading to fidelity, report two unanticipated aspects of fidelity suggesting that the polymerase active site is unique among family B members, and compare Pol ϵ fidelity to mutational specificity data in vivo to support a replication function. Purification of Yeast DNA Polymerase ϵ —A protease-deficient S. cerevisiae strain was constructed for this study by disrupting the PEP4 gene in strain GC379Δ (MATα ade5–1 lys2-Tn5–13 trp1–289 his7–2 leu2–3,112 ura3Δ, Ref. 28Shcherbakova P.V. Noskov V.N. Pshenichnov M.R. Pavlov Y.I. Mutat. Res. 1996; 369: 33-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar) using a heterologous kanMX cassette as described previously (29Wach A. Brachat A. Pohlmann R. Philippsen P. Yeast. 1994; 10: 1793-1808Crossref PubMed Scopus (2241) Google Scholar). The chromosomal POL2 allele of this strain was replaced with the pol2–4 allele as described previously (11Morrison A. Bell J.B. Kunkel T.A. Sugino A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 9473-9477Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). The pol2–4 mutation results in the FDIET → FAIAT amino acid replacement in the Exo I motif of Pol ϵ. Wild type Pol ϵ was overproduced in the POL2 + strain, and the exonuclease-deficient Pol ϵ with the FDIET → FAIAT substitution was overproduced in the pol2–4 strain. The enzymes were purified in parallel by conventional chromatography as described previously (17Chilkova O. Jonsson B.H. Johansson E. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 14082-14086Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Assay for 3′ → 5′ Exonuclease Activity—We used a primer, 5′-TTCTGTCTTCGAAGAGTAAA-3′, annealed to one of the two template oligonucleotides, 3′-AAGACAGAAGCTTCTCATTTTTTAACATGAACCGCCTAT-5 (S6 primer-template) or 3′-AAGACAGAAGCTTCTCATTCTTTAACATGAACCGCCTAT-5′ (S7 primer-template), as a substrate for the exonuclease reactions. The S6 substrate has a correctly matched primer terminus, and the S7 substrate has a mismatch at the 3′ end of the primer. The primer (0.8 μm) was labeled by 20 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP in a 100-μl reaction with 25 units of T4 polynucleotide kinase (New England Biolabs) for 1 h. The reaction was heated for 10 min at 56 °C and cleaned using a Qiagen nucleotide removal kit. The labeled product and unlabeled primer were annealed to the template in a final 100-μl volume at a ratio of 1 μm primer to 1.04 μm template by 5-min incubation at 86 °C and cooling to room temperature. The substrate (100 nm) was tested for completeness of annealing by performing a 10-min reaction with 15 nm Exo- T4 DNA polymerase and 50 μm dNTPs in a buffer described under “Processivity Assay.” Exo- T4 DNA polymerase was kindly provided by F. Kadyrov (30Kadyrov F.A. Drake J.W. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002; 30: 4387-4397Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Under these conditions, more than 95% of the primer was elongated. For determining exonuclease activity, 2.5 μl of substrate (50 nm) was incubated with various concentrations of Pol ϵ in a 50-μl reaction in standard buffer (50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 7.5, 8 mm MgCl2, 2 mm dithiothreitol, 100 μg/ml bovine serum albumin, 10% glycerol; see Ref. 31Maki S. Hashimoto K. Ohara T. Sugino A. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 21332-21341Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar) for 15 min. Ten μl of the reaction was mixed with 10 μl of deionized formamide dye solution, and 5 μl of the mixture was loaded on 18% urea-polyacrylamide gel and electrophoresed for 1.5 h at 80 watts. Processivity Assay—An oligonucleotide (PAGE-purified, Oligos Etc.) was annealed to a single-stranded M13mp2 DNA template such that DNA synthesis initiates at nucleotide 191 of the lacZ gene, 6 bases from the start of synthesis in the gap-filling mutagenesis assay (see below). The primer sequence was 5′-CGGAAACCAGGCAAAGCGCCATTCGCCATTCAGGCTGCGCAG-3′. The primer (0.8 μm) was labeled with 20 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP in a 100-μl reaction with 25 units of T4 polynucleotide kinase (New England Biolabs) for 1 h. The reaction was heated for 10 min at 56 °C and cleaned using a Qiagen nucleotide removal kit. Unlabeled primer and 10 μl of labeled primer were annealed in a total volume of 100 μl to single-stranded M13mp2 template DNA at a ratio of 0.25 μm primer to 0.25 μm template by 30-min incubation at 52.5 °C in 100 mm potassium acetate. After cooling to room temperature, the substrate was desalted using a Bio-Rad Micro Bio-Spin 30 column. When tested for complete annealing as described above, more than 80% of the primer was elongated. For processivity assays, the substrate (5 nm) was incubated with various concentrations (0.05–1 nm) of Pol ϵ (at 30 °C) and other polymerases (at 37 °C) in 50-μl reactions in standard buffer (see below) with 250 μm dNTPs for the times listed in the legend to Fig. 2. Ten μl of the reaction mixture was mixed with 10 μl of deionized formamide dye solution, and 5 μl of the mixture was loaded onto a 12% denaturing polyacrylamide gel and subjected to electrophoresis for 2 h at 80 watts. The catalytic subunits of human Exo- Pol γ and Pol α were kindly provided by W. Copeland (Refs. 32Longley M.J. Nguyen D. Kunkel T.A. Copeland W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 38555-38562Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar and 33Copeland W.C. Wang T.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 11028-11040Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, respectively). Buffers used were the following: for T4 Pol, 20 mm Tris-Cl, pH 7.5, 50 mm potassium acetate, 8 mm MgCl2, 5 mm dithiothreitol; for Pol γ, 25 mm HEPES, pH 7.5, 2 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 0.1 mm EDTA, 50 μg/ml bovine serum albumin, 5 mm MgCl2; and for Pol α, 20 mm Tris-Cl, pH 8.0, 8 mm MgCl2, 1 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 200 μg/ml bovine serum albumin. The sequencing ladder standard was produced by using the same substrate and a thermostable polymerase manual sequencing kit (U.S. Biochemical Corp.). Assay to Measure Polymerase Fidelity in Vitro—DNA synthesis fidelity was measured using the bacteriophage M13mp2 forward mutation assay described previously (34Bebenek K. Kunkel T.A. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 262: 217-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar). In brief, double-stranded M13mp2 DNA with a 407-nucleotide single-stranded region containing a portion of the lacZ gene was used a substrate for in vitro DNA synthesis. Reactions mixtures contained ∼1.5 nm DNA template, 50 mm Tris-Cl, pH 7.5, 8 mm MgCl2, 2 mm dithiothreitol, 100 μg/ml bovine serum albumin, 10% glycerol, 25 or 250 μm dNTPs, and 1.5–14 nm wild type or exonuclease-deficient Pol ϵ. Reactions were incubated at 30 °C for 10 min. Aliquots of the reactions were analyzed by agarose gel electrophoresis to confirm complete gap filling, and another aliquot of DNA was introduced into Escherichia coli to score the frequency of light blue and colorless plaques reflecting errors made during in vitro DNA synthesis. Single-stranded DNA was isolated from independent mutant plaques, and the lacZ gene was sequenced using either an ABI Prism 377 or ABI Prism 3100 sequencer. Error rates for individual types of mutation were calculated according to the following equation: ER = [(N i/N) × MF]/(D × 0.6) where N i is the number of mutations of a particular type, N is the total number of mutants analyzed, MF is frequency of lacZ mutants, D is the number of detectable sites for the particular type of mutation, and 0.6 is the probability of expressing a mutant lacZ allele in E. coli (34Bebenek K. Kunkel T.A. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 262: 217-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar). Yeast Strains for Measuring Forward Mutation Rates in Vivo—We started with derivatives of yeast strain CG379Δ containing the ura3–24 allele inserted into the BIK1 locus on chromosome III in two orientations relative to the nearest replication origin ARS306 (MATα ade5–1 lys2-Tn5–13 trp1–289 his7–2 leu2–3,112 ura3Δ bik1::ura3–24, Ref. 18Shcherbakova P.V. Pavlov Y.I. Genetics. 1996; 142: 717-726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). A. 1991; 88: 9473-9477Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). Ura+ revertants of these pol2–4 bik1::ura3–24 strains were obtained, yielding pol2–4 mutants with the wild type URA3 gene in two orientations relative to ARS306. The mismatch repair gene MSH6 was disrupted in the pol2–4 bik1::URA3 strains by the TRP1 gene as described previously (35Pavlov Y.I. Mian I.M. Kunkel T.A. Curr. Biol. 2003; 13: 744-748Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). Forward Mutation Assay in Vivo—Independent colonies of the pol2–4 msh6 bik1::URA3 derivatives of CG379Δ were streaked on yeast extract peptone dextrose plates, grown for 2 days at 30 °C, and replicaplated onto medium with 5-fluoroorotic acid (FOA) (36Boeke J.D. LaCroute F. Fink G.R. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1984; 197: 345-346Crossref PubMed Scopus (1712) Google Scholar) to select for ura3 mutants. One colony resistant to FOA (FOAr) was picked from each patch, and the URA3 open reading frame was amplified by PCR and sequenced by using either ABI Prism 377 or ABI Prism 3100 sequencer. The rate of FOAr mutation in the pol2–4 msh6 strains was measured by fluctuation analysis as described previously (37Shcherbakova P.V. Kunkel T.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 3177-3183Crossref PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar). The majority of FOAr colonies result from mutations in the URA3 gene in wild type strains (36Boeke J.D. LaCroute F. Fink G.R. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1984; 197: 345-346Crossref PubMed Scopus (1712) Google Scholar). For more accurate estimation of the ura3 mutation rate in the pol2–4 msh6 strains, we determined the proportion of FOAr mutants that were due to ura3 mutations in our fluctuation tests. To do this, the FOAr colonies were randomly picked and crossed to strain E68 (MAT a ade2–1 arg4–8 leu2–3,112 thr1–4 trp1–1 ura3–52 lys2Δ cup1–1) (37Shcherbakova P.V. Kunkel T.A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 3177-3183Crossref PubMed Scopus (156) Google Scholar). The hybrids were replica-plated onto medium lacking uracil to monitor complementation of the ura3–52 mutation. To estimate the ura3 mutation rate, the FOAr mutation rate was multiplied by the proportion of ura3 mutants among FOAr clones. Purity and 3′ → 5′ Exonuclease Activity of Wild Type and Mutant Pol ϵ —We recently described purification of the four-subunit S. cerevisiae Pol ϵ complex in 1:1:1:1 stoichiometry (17Chilkova O. Jonsson B.H. Johansson E. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 14082-14086Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Here we used this procedure to overproduce and purify wild type Pol ϵ and a variant with a double amino acid change (D289A,E291A) in the Exo I motif of the catalytic subunit. Both protein preparations contained all four subunits in the expected ratios (Fig. 1A). The additional faint bands seen on the colloidal Coomassie-stained gel represent minor contaminants and not Pol2 proteolytic fragments as confirmed by Western blot analysis with polyclonal antibodies to Pol2 (data not shown). The double amino acid change in the exonuclease active site of the catalytic subunit was previously shown to reduce the 3′ → 5′ exonuclease activity of Pol ϵ with no significant effect on polymerization activity (11Morrison A. Bell J.B. Kunkel T.A. Sugino A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 9473-9477Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar, 27Shimizu K. Hashimoto K. Kirchner J.M. Nakai W. Nishikawa H. Resnick M.A. Sugino A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 37422-37429Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). When we examined our enzyme preparations for exonuclease activity, wild type Pol ϵ readily digested a labeled, correctly paired DNA primer (Fig. 1B, lanes 2–4). No digestion was seen for the Pol ϵ D289A, E291A preparation (lanes 5–7). Similar results were obtained when a primer with a terminal mismatched nucleotide was used as a substrate for the exonuclease reaction (data not shown). Therefore the catalytic subunit of the Pol ϵ D289A,E291A as well as the three accessory subunits lacks 3′ → 5′ exonuclease activity detectable in this assay. Processivity of Pol ϵ —Next we compared the processivity of DNA synthesis by Pol ϵ D289A,E291A to that of several other B family DNA polymerases (Fig. 2). Reactions were performed with excess primer-template over polymerase such that once the polymerase synthesizes DNA and dissociates the probability of using the extended product again is very low (see legend to Fig. 2 for further details). Analysis of the products of the reactions catalyzed by exonuclease-deficient variants of Pol ϵ, T4 Pol (gp43 protein only), and Pol γ (catalytic subunit only) shows that all three enzymes terminate synthesis at numerous template positions (Fig. 2). Some of the sites of frequent termination are shared by the three polymerases, while others are not shared, suggesting that these polymerases interact somewhat differently with template-primers even in the same DNA sequence context. All three polymerases incorporated up to 170 nucleotides in one cycle of polymerization (up to approximately template nucleotide 20, Fig. 2). Maximum processivity could be even higher with other DNA templates since the termination band observed at position 20 corresponds to the location of the palindromic lacZ operator sequence. The DNA synthesis reached this point in 11% of the Pol ϵ reactions as compared with 6 and 3% for T4 Pol and Pol γ, respectively (the values are calculated by phosphorimagery as the amount of product at that location divided by the total products). This suggests that Pol ϵ holoenzyme is the most processive of these three replicative polymerases. Additional studies will be required to determine whether high processivity is intrinsic to the catalytic subunit of Pol ϵ or is influenced by the accessory subunits. In contrast to Pol ϵ, T4 Pol, and Pol γ and in agreement with earlier studies (50Wang T.S. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1991; 60: 513-552Crossref PubMed Scopus (452) Google Scholar, 51Fisher P.A. Wang T.S. Korn D. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 6128-6137Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 52Copeland W.C. Wang T.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22739-22748Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), the catalytic subunit of human Pol α is less processive, incorporating from 1 to about 20 nucleotides per cycle. Fidelity of Wild Type Pol ϵ —We first analyzed fidelity of the wild type Pol ϵ during gap-filling DNA synthesis using the M13mp2 forward mutation assay (see “Experimental Procedures”). Agarose gel electrophoresis demonstrated that Pol ϵ filled the 407-nucleotide gap (data not shown but similar to Fig. 3 in Ref. 34Bebenek K. Kunkel T.A. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 262: 217-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar). The frequency of lacZ mutants obtained after transfection of E. coli with these reaction products (0.00194, Table I) was reproducibly only slightly elevated over the background mutant frequency measured upon transfection with the unfilled gapped DNA subs

Adenylate cyclase toxin (CyaA) is one of the major virulence factors produced by Bordetella pertussis, the whooping cough agent. CyaA belongs to the repeat in toxin protein family and requires a post-translational fatty acylation to form cation-selective channels in target cell membranes and to penetrate into cytosol. We have demonstrated recently that CyaA uses the αMβ2 integrin (CD11b/CD18) as a specific cellular receptor. Here we show that the acylation of CyaA is required for a productive and tight interaction of the toxin with cells expressing CD11b. In addition, we demonstrate that the catalytic domain is not required for binding of CyaA to CD11b and that the main integrin interacting domain of CyaA is located in its glycine/aspartate-rich repeat region. These data decipher, for the first time, the interaction of CyaA with CD11b-positive cells and open new prospects for understanding the interaction of Bordetella pertussis with innate and adaptive immune systems. Adenylate cyclase toxin (CyaA) is one of the major virulence factors produced by Bordetella pertussis, the whooping cough agent. CyaA belongs to the repeat in toxin protein family and requires a post-translational fatty acylation to form cation-selective channels in target cell membranes and to penetrate into cytosol. We have demonstrated recently that CyaA uses the αMβ2 integrin (CD11b/CD18) as a specific cellular receptor. Here we show that the acylation of CyaA is required for a productive and tight interaction of the toxin with cells expressing CD11b. In addition, we demonstrate that the catalytic domain is not required for binding of CyaA to CD11b and that the main integrin interacting domain of CyaA is located in its glycine/aspartate-rich repeat region. These data decipher, for the first time, the interaction of CyaA with CD11b-positive cells and open new prospects for understanding the interaction of Bordetella pertussis with innate and adaptive immune systems. Bordetella pertussis is the etiological agent of whooping cough, a highly contagious childhood respiratory disease, characterized by bronchopneumonia and paroxysmal coughing interrupted by inspiratory whoops. Among the variety of toxins produced by B. pertussis, the adenylate cyclase (CyaA) 1The abbreviations used are: CyaA, adenylate cyclase toxin; RTX, repeat in toxin family protein; AC, adenylate cyclase; Hly, hemolysin moiety; OVA, ovalbumin; mAb, monoclonal antibody(s); CHO, Chinese hamster ovary cell; PE, phycoerythrin; MFI, mean fluorescence intensity; FACS, fluorescence-activated cell sorter; biotin-HPDP, N-(6-(biotinamido)hexyl)-3′-(2′-pyridyldithio) propiamide.1The abbreviations used are: CyaA, adenylate cyclase toxin; RTX, repeat in toxin family protein; AC, adenylate cyclase; Hly, hemolysin moiety; OVA, ovalbumin; mAb, monoclonal antibody(s); CHO, Chinese hamster ovary cell; PE, phycoerythrin; MFI, mean fluorescence intensity; FACS, fluorescence-activated cell sorter; biotin-HPDP, N-(6-(biotinamido)hexyl)-3′-(2′-pyridyldithio) propiamide. is a crucial factor in the virulence strategy of the bacteria during the early phases of respiratory tract colonization (1Goodwin M.S. Weiss A.A. Infect. Immun. 1990; 58: 3445-3447Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Khelef N. Sakamoto H. Guiso N. Microb. Pathog. 1992; 12: 227-235Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). The toxin allows the pathogen to escape host immune surveillance, mainly by intoxicating neutrophils and macrophages causing phagocyte impotence and inducing macrophage apoptosis (3Confer D.L. Eaton J.W. Science. 1982; 217: 948-950Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar, 4Gueirard P. Druilhe A. Pretolani M. Guiso N. Infect. Immun. 1998; 66: 1718-1725Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 5Harvill E.T. Cotter P.A. Yuk M.H. Miller J.F. Infect. Immun. 1999; 67: 1493-1500Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Khelef N. Guiso N. FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 1995; 134: 27-32Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 7Khelef N. Zychlinsky A. Guiso N. Infect. Immun. 1993; 61: 4064-4071Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The role of CyaA in the pathogenesis of B. pertussis was clearly demonstrated in the mouse respiratory model. Indeed, genetically modified B. pertussis strains deficient in the expression of CyaA were impaired in their ability to induce pulmonary lesions and to cause lethal infection (8Khelef N. Bachelet C.M. Vargaftig B.B. Guiso N. Infect. Immun. 1994; 62: 2893-2900Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Weiss A.A. Goodwin M.S. Infect. Immun. 1989; 57: 3757-3764Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). On the other hand, CyaA was shown to induce protective immunity against B. pertussis lung colonization in a mouse model (10Betsou F. Sebo P. Guiso N. Infect. Immun. 1993; 61: 3583-3589Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Betsou F. Sebo P. Guiso N. Infect. Immun. 1995; 63: 3309-3315Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 12Hormozi K. Parton R. Coote J. FEMS Immunol. Med. Microbiol. 1999; 23: 273-282Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). CyaA is a 1706-amino acid-long polypeptide consisting of four functional domains: the adenylate cyclase activity (AC) domain (residues 1–400), the hydrophobic channel-forming domain (residues 500–700), the calcium-binding glycine/aspartate-rich repeat domain (residues 1000–1600), and the C-terminal domain harboring a secretion signal (residues 1600–1706). CyaA is able to invade eukaryotic cells and translocate its catalytic domain into the cytoplasm where, upon activation by endogenous calmodulin, it catalyzes the conversion of ATP into cAMP (13Ladant D. Ullmann A. Trends Microbiol. 1999; 7: 172-176Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar). The accumulation of cAMP in the cell cytosol is considered to be responsible for the toxic effect of this toxin (14Rogel A. Meller R. Hanski E. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 3154-3161Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The main consequences of this intoxication are cell apoptosis and the alteration of phagocytic abilities and superoxide production (3Confer D.L. Eaton J.W. Science. 1982; 217: 948-950Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar, 7Khelef N. Zychlinsky A. Guiso N. Infect. Immun. 1993; 61: 4064-4071Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 15Friedman R.L. Fiederlein R.L. Glasser L. Galgiani J.N. Infect. Immun. 1987; 55: 135-140Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 16Njamkepo E. Pinot F. Francois D. Guiso N. Polla B.S. Bachelet M. J. Cell. Physiol. 2000; 183: 91-99Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 17Pearson R.D. Symes P. Conboy M. Weiss A.A. Hewlett E.L. J. Immunol. 1987; 139: 2749-2754PubMed Google Scholar).CyaA requires calcium to acquire a translocation-specific conformation that allows the delivery of the catalytic domain into the cell cytosol (18Rogel A. Hanski E. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 22599-22605Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Rose T. Sebo P. Bellalou J. Ladant D. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 26370-26376Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar). CyaA is first produced as an inactive protoxin, pro-CyaA, and it is converted to the active toxin upon post-translational fatty acyl modification that is catalyzed by the accessory protein acyltransferase, the product of the cyaC gene. Acylation of pro-CyaA consists of covalent palmitoylation at the ϵ-amino groups of two lysine residues, Lys-983 and Lys-860, located within conserved RTX acylation sites (20Barry E.M. Weiss A.A. Ehrmann I.E. Gray M.C. Hewlett E.L. Goodwin M.S. J. Bacteriol. 1991; 173: 720-726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 21Hackett M. Guo L. Shabanowitz J. Hunt D.F. Hewlett E.L. Science. 1994; 266: 433-435Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar), located within conserved RTX acylation sites (20Barry E.M. Weiss A.A. Ehrmann I.E. Gray M.C. Hewlett E.L. Goodwin M.S. J. Bacteriol. 1991; 173: 720-726Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 21Hackett M. Guo L. Shabanowitz J. Hunt D.F. Hewlett E.L. Science. 1994; 266: 433-435Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar). Although acylation of Lys-860 seems not to be necessary for CyaA activity, acylation of Lys-983 was shown to be crucial (22Basar T. Havlicek V. Bezouskova S. Hackett M. Sebo P. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 348-354Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). The covalent post-translational fatty acylation is required for translocation of the catalytic AC domain of the toxin through target cell membranes, as well as for the formation of hemolytic cation-selective CyaA channels.CyaA can penetrate at least to some extent a wide range of cell types, including the mammalian erythrocytes lacking membrane trafficking (18Rogel A. Hanski E. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 22599-22605Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Bellalou J. Sakamoto H. Ladant D. Geoffroy C. Ullmann A. Infect. Immun. 1990; 58: 3242-3247Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 24Gray M.C. Ross W. Kim K. Hewlett E.L. Infect. Immun. 1999; 67: 4393-4399Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). However, CyaA toxicity effects such as the abrogation of phagocytic capacity and the induction of apoptosis were mainly elucidated on immune cells, namely neutrophils and macrophages (3Confer D.L. Eaton J.W. Science. 1982; 217: 948-950Crossref PubMed Scopus (287) Google Scholar, 7Khelef N. Zychlinsky A. Guiso N. Infect. Immun. 1993; 61: 4064-4071Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, CyaA was shown to display specific intoxication toward alveolar macrophages and to play a key role in mouse respiratory infection by B. pertussis (4Gueirard P. Druilhe A. Pretolani M. Guiso N. Infect. Immun. 1998; 66: 1718-1725Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). We have demonstrated recently (25Guermonprez P. Khelef N. Blouin E. Rieu P. Ricciardi-Castagnoli P. Guiso N. Ladant D. Leclerc C. J. Exp. Med. 2001; 193: 1035-1044Crossref PubMed Scopus (270) Google Scholar) that CyaA binds specifically to target cells through the αMβ2 integrin (CD11b/CD18) receptor. This binding was saturable and completely inhibited by anti-CD11b monoclonal antibodies. CyaA displayed a selective cytotoxicity toward CD11b+ cells showing that its interaction with CD11b is required for the translocation of the catalytic domain and the subsequent increase of intracellular cAMP concentration and cell death. Moreover, sensitivity of CHO cells to CyaA cytotoxicity was dramatically increased upon expression of the CD11b/CD18 heterodimer. Furthermore, Ca2+ ions that are required for translocation of the catalytic domain into cells were also strictly necessary for CyaA interaction with CD11b (25Guermonprez P. Khelef N. Blouin E. Rieu P. Ricciardi-Castagnoli P. Guiso N. Ladant D. Leclerc C. J. Exp. Med. 2001; 193: 1035-1044Crossref PubMed Scopus (270) Google Scholar). The importance of CD11b for interaction of CyaA with cells was further demonstrated in a system where CyaA is used as a vector to deliver foreign antigens into antigen-presenting cells, such as dendritic cells. Only dendritic cells of the CD11c+ CD8α–CD11bhigh subset were, indeed, able to display major histocompatibility complex class I peptide complexes corresponding to the epitope inserted in the recombinant CyaA (26Guermonprez P. Fayolle C. Rojas M.J. Rescigno M. Ladant D. Leclerc C. Eur. J. Immunol. 2002; 32: 3071-3081Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar).The CD11b protein is a member of the large family of β2 integrins, the leukocyte adhesion molecules, which comprises LFA1 (CD11a), MAC-1 (CD11b), and p150,95 (CD11c). The members of this family differ by their α-chain, which is expressed as an obligate heterodimer with a β-chain (CD18) (27Arnaout M.A. Blood. 1990; 75: 1037-1050Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). CD11b, also known as complement type 3 receptor (CR3), is expressed on macrophages, neutrophils, dendritic cells, NK cells, peritoneal B-1 cells, and a subset of CD8+ T cells (27Arnaout M.A. Blood. 1990; 75: 1037-1050Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 28Bell D. Young J.W. Banchereau J. Adv. Immunol. 1999; 72: 255-324Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). It plays a key role in leukocyte adhesive functions and triggers phagocytosis of complement-coated particles (29Diamond M.S. Springer T.A. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 120: 545-556Crossref PubMed Scopus (453) Google Scholar). CD11b binds various ligands, such as the intracellular adhesion molecule ICAM-1, fibrinogen, coagulant factor X, and inactivated complement component C3b (iC3b) (30Altieri D.C. Edgington T.S. J. Immun. 2000; 68: 247-256Crossref PubMed Google Scholar).Production of Anti-CyaA Monoclonal Antibodies—BALB/c mice were initially immunized intraperitoneally with CyaA toxin (20 μg in alum). At approximately 2-week intervals, mice were boosted 3 times with 10 μg of CyaA in alum. Throughout the immunization protocol, mice were bled and their sera tested for the presence of anti-CyaA antibodies by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. When significant sera titers were detected, a last boost was given to these mice, and their splenocytes were fused with P3X63 myeloma cells (ATCC, Manassas, VA) 3 days later. The generated hybridomas were screened for the production of CyaA-specific monoclonal antibodies (mAb) by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Highly productive hybridomas were then selected and cloned by single-cell limiting dilutions and subsequently used to make ascites in BALB/c nude mice to generate large amounts of anti-CyaA mAb. The mAb were purified from ascites using T-Gel™ purification kit (Pierce) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The antibody concentration was measured with Bio-Rad protein assay. Two of these monoclonal antibodies were used in this study: antibody 5G12 that reacts with an epitope localized within amino acids 1–190, and antibody 6D7 that reacts with an epitope localized within amino acids 1006–1706 (data not shown).Cells and Culture—Chinese hamster ovary cells transfected with human CD11b/CD18 (CHO-CD11b cells), human CD11c/CD18 (CHO-CD11c cells), or transfected with the vector alone (CHO cells) were a kind gift of D. Golenbock (Boston University School of Medicine, Boston) and were cultured in the presence of neomycin as described previously (41Ingalls R.R. Arnaout M.A. Delude R.L. Flaherty S. Savedra Jr., R. Golenbock D.T. Prog. Clin. Biol. Res. 1998; 397: 107-117PubMed Google Scholar).Antibodies—Monoclonal antibodies specific for human CD11b (ICRF44, mouse IgG1, κ) and human CD11c (B-Ly6, mouse IgG1, κ) were purchased from Pharmingen.Binding Assays—The assays were performed as described previously (25Guermonprez P. Khelef N. Blouin E. Rieu P. Ricciardi-Castagnoli P. Guiso N. Ladant D. Leclerc C. J. Exp. Med. 2001; 193: 1035-1044Crossref PubMed Scopus (270) Google Scholar). Briefly, 2 × 105 cells were incubated with the indicated concentrations of CyaA molecules in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium containing 4.5 mg/ml glucose (Invitrogen), without serum, in 96-well culture plates for 30 min on ice. After washing, anti-CyaA catalytic domain mAb (5G12) or anti-CyaA repeat domain mAb (6D7) was added at 25 μg/ml. In some experiments, cells were preincubated with the indicated concentrations of CyaA molecules for 30 min on ice. Then CyaA-biotin (30 nm), anti-CD11b mAb (2 μg/ml), or anti-CD11c mAb (2 μg/ml) (Pharmingen) were added separately in the continuous presence of the toxins.After washing and removing supernatant, cells were stained with goat anti-mouse IgG-PE (Caltag, Le Perray en Yvelines, France) or with streptavidin-PE (Pharmingen) at 1:300 dilution. After the last wash, cells were analyzed by flow cytometry on a FACStar™ (BD Biosciences) in the presence of 5 μg/ml propidium iodide. Aggregated and dead cells were subtracted by gatings based on propidium iodide exclusion. The binding data were deduced from the mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) and expressed as ΔMFI = (MFI value of cells incubated with CyaA) – (MFI value of cells incubated without CyaA) or as percentage of binding = (sample binding)/(maximum binding) × 100. The maximum binding corresponds to (MFI value of cells incubated with CyaA or anti-CD11b in the absence of competitor) – (MFI value of cells incubated with medium alone). The sample binding corresponds to (MFI value of cells incubated with CyaA or anti-CD11b in the presence of competitor) – (MFI value of cells incubated with medium alone).Cyclic AMP Assay—Cyclic AMP accumulated in cells exposed to the CyaA toxin was performed essentially as described previously (25Guermonprez P. Khelef N. Blouin E. Rieu P. Ricciardi-Castagnoli P. Guiso N. Ladant D. Leclerc C. J. Exp. Med. 2001; 193: 1035-1044Crossref PubMed Scopus (270) Google Scholar). Briefly, 5 × 105 cells were incubated with the indicated concentrations of CyaA in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium + glucose for 20 min at 37 °C. After washing, cAMP accumulated in cell cytosol was released by lysis with 0.1 n HCl and boiling for 5 min at 120 °C. After neutralization with 0.1 n NaOH, the samples were then added to microtiter plates previously coated with a cAMP-bovine serum albumin conjugate and then incubated with an appropriate dilution of anti-cAMP rabbit anti-serum. After washing, anti-cAMP antibodies were revealed with anti-rabbit antibodies coupled to alkaline phosphatase. The cAMP content of each sample was determined from comparison with a standard curve obtained by adding known cAMP concentration.Binding of Recombinant CyaAs to Erythrocytes—Toxin binding to sheep erythrocytes was assayed essentially as described previously (38Karimova G. Fayolle C. Gmira S. Ullmann A. Leclerc C. Ladant D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 12532-12537Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). Toxins in 8 m urea, 20 mm Hepes-Na were directly diluted (at least 200-fold) into suspensions of sheep erythrocytes (5 × 108/ml) in buffer A (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 150 mm NaCl, 2 mm CaCl2) and incubated at 37 °C for 30 min. An aliquot was removed to determine the total adenylate cyclase activity added to each sample. The cell suspensions were chilled on ice and centrifuged 5 min at 3,000 × g and 4 °C. The pelleted cells were resuspended in buffer A; the suspension was transferred to fresh tubes to avoid carryover of toxin bound to tube walls, and cells were pelleted again by centrifugation and finally lysed with 0.1% Triton X-100. The enzymatic AC activities in the cell extracts corresponded to that of the toxin associated with the cellular membrane and was expressed as a percentage of total activity added to the cells. The adenylate cyclase activity was measured as described previously (40Ladant D. Glaser P. Ullmann A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 2244-2250Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). One unit of adenylate cyclase activity corresponds to 1 μmol of cAMP formed in 1 min at 30 °C and pH 8.0.RESULTSCyaA Specifically Binds to CD11b + Cells and Inhibits CyaA-biotin and Anti-CD11b Binding to CD11b + Cells—In order to investigate the role of biological and structural properties of CyaA in its interaction with CD11b, we developed two complementary assays: a binding assay and a competition assay. In the binding assay, CyaA molecules were incubated either with transfected CHO cells expressing human CD11b/CD18 (CHO-CD11b cells) or with mock transfected CHO cells, and subsequently, the cell-associated toxin was detected with an anti-CyaA monoclonal antibody (5G12) specific for the catalytic domain. As shown in Fig. 1A, using this assay, CyaA binding was specifically detected on CD11b+ cells. In the competition assay, different CyaA molecules (mutants or fragments) were tested for their ability to compete with binding of CyaA-biotin or anti-CD11b mAb to CD11b+ cells. Here the CHO-CD11b cells were incubated with CyaA at different concentrations for 30 min on ice. Then CyaA-biotin (30 nm) or anti-CD11b mAb (2 μg/ml) were added in the continuous presence of CyaA, and their binding to the cells was evaluated by FACS. As shown in Fig. 1B, CyaA efficiently inhibited both CyaA-biotin and anti-CD11b binding to CHO-CD11b cells in a dose-dependent manner. This inhibitory effect was specific for CD11b since CyaA was unable to compete with another ligand (anti-CD11c mAb) for its specific receptor (CD11c) expressed by CHO cells (Fig. 1B).Lack of CyaA Acylation Affects Its Binding to CD11b + Cells— Because it is well established that CyaA needs a post-translational palmitoylation to acquire its invasive activity and capacity to form hemolytic membrane channels, we tested whether the lack of acylation affects CyaA interaction with CD11b+ cells. In a binding assay, control CHO cells or CHO-CD11b cells were incubated with either CyaA or the non-acylated pro-CyaA. The binding was evaluated using a monoclonal antibody recognizing the catalytic domain of CyaA (AC). As shown in (Fig. 2A), at low concentrations, binding of both CyaA and pro-CyaA molecules to CD11b+ cells was rather comparable, with a slightly more efficient binding of the acylated CyaA. This could be due to its enhanced interaction with cell membrane, a better adapted conformation of CyaA for binding and/or higher affinity of the acylated CyaA for the CD11b receptor. Indeed, the pro-CyaA binding reached saturation at substantially higher protoxin concentrations, as compared with CyaA binding. The simplest explanation of this observation would be that pro-CyaA binds CD11b+ cells with lower affinity than CyaA. At high protoxin concentration, aggregates and/or oligomers of pro-CyaA would bind to the cells, and consequently, higher amounts of pro-CyaA would be detected. In contrast, very low binding of CyaA or pro-CyaA to control CHO cells was detected.Fig. 2Direct binding of CyaA or pro-CyaA to CHO transfectants. A, CHO-CD11b cells (▪, ▴) or CHO cells (□, ▵) were incubated with the indicated concentrations of CyaA (▪, □) or pro-CyaA (▴, ▵). Surface-bound CyaA was detected with anti-CyaA mAb (5G12). Results are expressed as ΔMFI = (MFI value of cells incubated with CyaA) – (MFI value of cells incubated without CyaA) and are representative of two independent experiments. B and C, CHO-CD11b cells were preincubated with the indicated concentrations of CyaA or pro-CyaA. CyaA-biotin (B) or anti-CD11b mAb (C) was then added, in the continuous presence of CyaA or pro-CyaA. Surface-bound CyaA-biotin or anti-CD11b mAb was measured by FACS. Results are expressed as percentage of binding = (sample binding)/(maximum binding) × 100 and are representative of at least two independent experiments.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)Acylation Stabilizes Interaction of CyaA with CD11b + Cells— To analyze further the role of acylation in interaction of the toxin with CD11b+ cells, we tested the ability of non-acylated pro-CyaA to compete with CyaA for binding to CHO-CD11b cells. As shown in Fig. 2B, when compared with the acylated CyaA, the non-acylated pro-CyaA exhibited a substantially reduced capacity to compete with biotinylated CyaA for binding to CD11b+ cells. To determine whether the lack of inhibition was due to an inefficient interaction with CD11b, we evaluated the capacity of pro-CyaA to block anti-CD11b binding to CHO-CD11b cells. Indeed, as compared with CyaA, pro-CyaA was unable to inhibit binding of the anti-CD11b mAb to the CHO-CD11b cells (Fig. 2C).Because supraphysiological production of cAMP and cell intoxication are the consequences of CyaA interaction with CD11b+ cells, we then analyzed, using the CHO-CD11b cells, if these toxin functions are dependent on CyaA acylation. As expected, the pro-CyaA did not induce any cAMP increase in CHO-CD11b cells (Fig. 3A) and had no significant cytotoxic effect on these cells, as compared with the acylated CyaA (Fig. 3B). Taken together, these results clearly demonstrate that acylation of CyaA is necessary for a functional interaction of the toxin with CD11b+ cells and that the binding of pro-CyaA to CD11b is non-productive and does not trigger cytotoxic effects on CD11b-expressing cells.Fig. 3CyaA acylation is required for CyaA induced-cAMP accumulation and cytotoxicity. CHO-CD11b cells were incubated with either CyaA or pro-CyaA at the indicated concentrations for 20 min at 37 °C. Then cells were lysed and cAMP was measured (A). In parallel, toxicity was determined by measuring the amount of lactate dehydrogenase released in the medium after incubation of CHO-CD11b cells for 4 h at 37 °C in the presence of the indicated concentrations of either CyaA or pro-CyaA (B). Results are representative of at least two independent experiments.View Large

In plants, γ-aminobutyrate (GABA), a non-protein amino acid, accumulates rapidly in response to a variety of abiotic stresses such as oxygen deficiency. Under normoxia, GABA is catabolized to succinic semialdehyde and then to succinate with the latter reaction being catalyzed by succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase (SSADH). Complementation of an SSADH-deficient yeast mutant with an Arabidopsis cDNA library enabled the identification of a novel cDNA (designated as AtGH-BDH for Arabidopsis thaliana γ-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase), which encodes a 289-amino acid polypeptide containing an NADP-binding domain. Constitutive expression of AtGHBDH in the mutant yeast enabled growth on 20 mm GABA and significantly enhanced the cellular concentrations of γ-hydroxybutyrate, the product of the GHDBH reaction. These data confirm that the cDNA encodes a polypeptide with GHBDH activity. Arabidopsis plants subjected to flooding-induced oxygen deficiency for up to 4 h possessed elevated concentrations of γ-hydroxybutyrate as well as GABA and alanine. RNA expression analysis revealed that GHBDH transcription was not up-regulated by oxygen deficiency. These findings suggest that GHBDH activity is regulated by the supply of succinic semialdehyde or by redox balance. It is proposed that GHBDH and SSADH activities in plants are regulated in a complementary fashion and that GHBDH and γ-hydroxybutyrate function in oxidative stress tolerance. Constitutive expression of AtGHBDH in the mutant yeast enabled growth on 20 mm GABA and significantly enhanced the cellular concentrations of γ-hydroxybutyrate, the product of the GHDBH reaction. These data confirm that the cDNA encodes a polypeptide with GHBDH activity.
